query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 O dolce amor che di riso t’ammanti, 14 quanto parevi ardente in que’ flailli, 15 ch’avieno spirto sol di pensier santi!
16 Poscia che i cari e lucidi lapilli 17 ond’ io vidi ingemmato il sesto lume 18 puoser silenzio a li angelici squilli,
19 udir mi parve un mormorar di fiume 20 che scende chiaro giù di pietra in pietra, 21 mostrando l’ubertà del suo cacume.
query.result:
**English:**
13 O sweet love that delightest in laughter, 14 how ardent you appeared in those flames, 15 which had their spirit only from holy thoughts!
16 After the dear and shining jewels 17 with which I saw the sixth light adorned 18 had silenced the angelic trumpets,
19 I seemed to hear the murmur of a river 20 that descends clearly down from stone to stone, 21 showing the abundance of its source.
**Old English:**
13 Eala ðu swettolufu ðe ðu ðæs hleahtres gewilnast, 14 hu ðu ðuhte ðæt ðu wære byrnende on ðæm legum, 15 ða ðe næfdon ðone gast buton ðurh ða halgan ðohtas!
16 Æfter ðæm ðe ða dyran and ða beorhtan gimmas 17 ðurh ða ðe ic ðone sixte leoman geseah bewrigenne 18 ða ða ða engliscan byman ða geswugodon,
19 ða ðuhte ðæt ic gehyrde ðæs wæteres hlud, 20 ðæt of ðæm stane on ðone stan niðer stigeð, 21 and ðæs wæteres mægen ðurh ða heanesse ðæs wæteres ætywode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 E come suono al collo de la cetra 23 prende sua forma, e sì com’ al pertugio 24 de la sampogna vento che penètra,
25 così, rimosso d’aspettare indugio, 26 quel mormorar de l’aguglia salissi 27 su per lo collo, come fosse bugio.
query.result:
**English:**
22 And as sound at the neck of the lute 23 takes its form, and as at the hole 24 of the pipe wind that penetrates,
25 so, removed from the delay of waiting, 26 that murmuring of the eagle rose up 27 along its neck, as if it were a horn.
**Old English:**
22 And swa swebg on halse hearpan 23 onfehð his hiw, and swa swa ðurh gatu 24 pipegæstes wind ðe ðurh ðringð,
25 swa ðurh ðæs earnes hals ðone hleodor, 26 atol æglæca, up gewat ðurh wendung, 27 swa ðurh hornpipe ðone sweg sende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Fecesi voce quivi, e quindi uscissi 29 per lo suo becco in forma di parole, 30 quali aspettava il core ov’ io le scrissi.
query.result:
**English:**
28 There a voice was made, and then it came forth 29 through its beak in the form of words, 30 which the heart where I wrote them was expecting.
**Old English:**
28 Þær wearð æfter stefne, and ða út com 29 ðurh his neb on wera wisan, 30 swa ðæt ðæt heorte onfand ðe ic hit ær on wrat.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 «La parte in me che vede e pate il sole 32 ne l’aguglie mortali», incominciommi, 33 «or fisamente riguardar si vole,
34 perché d’i fuochi ond’ io figura fommi, 35 quelli onde l’occhio in testa mi scintilla, 36 e’ di tutti lor gradi son li sommi.
query.result:
**English:**
31 "The part of me that sees and suffers the sun 32 in mortal eyes," he began to say to me, 33 "now you must gaze at intently,
34 because of the fires from which I take my form, 35 those from which the eyes in my head sparkle, 36 and I am the highest of all their ranks.
**Old English:**
31 "Se ðæl on me ðe ðone sunne gesihð and ðolað 32 on ðam deadlicum eagum," he ða to me cwæð, 33 "ðu scealt nu ðurh ða ðinra eagna gesihðe,
34 ðara fyra ðe ic of afyrmod, 35 ðara ðe ðin eage on ðinum heafde scinð, 36 and ic eom ðara ðara ðe ðe betste syndon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Colui che luce in mezzo per pupilla, 38 fu il cantor de lo Spirito Santo, 39 che l’arca traslatò di villa in villa:
40 ora conosce il merto del suo canto, 41 in quanto effetto fu del suo consiglio, 42 per lo remunerar ch’è altrettanto.
query.result:
**English:**
37 He who shines in the midst through the pupil, 38 was the singer of the Holy Spirit, 39 who translated the ark from town to town:
40 now he knows the merit of his song, 41 inasmuch as it was the effect of his counsel, 42 for the reward which is just as much.
**Old English:**
37 Se ðe on middes lihteð ðurh ða sihðe, 38 wæs ðæs Halgan Gastes sangere, 39 se ðe ða earce ferode of tune to tune:
40 nu he ðæs lofscipe his songes cann, 41 forðæm ðe hit wæs ðæs redes gecynde, 42 ðurh ða edleane ðe ðær efen sind.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Dei cinque che mi fan cerchio per ciglio, 44 colui che più al becco mi s’accosta, 45 la vedovella consolò del figlio:
46 ora conosce quanto caro costa 47 non seguir Cristo, per l’esperïenza 48 di questa dolce vita e de l’opposta.
query.result:
**English:**
43 Of the five who make a circle for me with their brows, 44 he who is closest to my beak, 45 consoled the widow for her son:
46 now he knows how dearly it costs 47 not to follow Christ, through the experience 48 of this sweet life and its opposite.
**Old English:**
43 Of ðæm fif ðe me ymb feðan mid ðæm bræwe, 44 se ðe nehsta ðæs nebban me wæs, 45 ðone wuduwan he gefrefrode be ðæm suna:
46 nu he wat ðæt hit wyrðe bið 47 Criste næfre ne folgian, ðurh ða gecnysse 48 ðyses wynsuman lifes and ðæs wipermalan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 E quel che segue in la circunferenza 50 di che ragiono, per l’arco superno, 51 morte indugiò per vera penitenza:
52 ora conosce che ’l giudicio etterno 53 non si trasmuta, quando degno preco 54 fa crastino là giù de l’odïerno.
query.result:
**English:**
49 And that which follows in the circumference 50 of which I speak, by the arch above, 51 death delayed through true repentance:
52 now he knows that the eternal judgment 53 is not changed, when a worthy prayer 54 makes tomorrow there below of today.
**Old English:**
49 And ðæt ðe folgað on ðære ymbhwyrfte 50 ðæs ðe ic secge, ðurh ðone oferestan bogan, 51 deað oferhogað ðurh soðe dædbote:
52 nu he oncnæwð ðæt ðæt ece dom 53 ne bið awend, ðonne weorðlic bøn 54 ðær niðan ðone todæglican dæg ðone mornegedæð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 L’altro che segue, con le leggi e meco, 56 sotto buona intenzion che fé mal frutto, 57 per cedere al pastor si fece greco:
58 ora conosce come il mal dedutto 59 dal suo bene operar non li è nocivo, 60 avvegna che sia ’l mondo indi distrutto.
query.result:
**English:**
55 The other, who follows, with the laws and with me, 56 under good intention that bore evil fruit, 57 to yield to the shepherd made himself Greek:
58 now he knows how the evil deduced 59 from his good work is not harmful to him, 60 although the world is destroyed thereby.
**Old English:**
55 Se ðe oðer ðe ðær æfter fylgð, mid ðam gesetum and mid me, 56 ðurh ða godan ðeaw ðe yfele wæstm bær, 57 for ðam ðe he wolde ðam hyrde gehyrsumian, he worhte hine sylfne to Grecisce:
58 nu he cann ðæt ðæt yfel ðe of ðam godan weorce com him nis nawiht derigende, 59 ðeah ðe ðeos world ðurh ðæt forwurde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 E quel che vedi ne l’arco declivo, 62 Guiglielmo fu, cui quella terra plora 63 che piagne Carlo e Federigo vivo:
64 ora conosce come s’innamora 65 lo ciel del giusto rege, e al sembiante 66 del suo fulgore il fa vedere ancora.
query.result:
**English:**
61 And he whom you see in the descending arc, 62 was William, for whom that land weeps 63 that Charles and Frederick mourn while still alive:
64 now he knows how Heaven falls in love 65 with a just king, and with his splendor's likeness 66 he makes it visible once more.
**Old English:**
61 And se ðe ðu on ðam bogan gesihst, 62 ðæt wæs Willelm, ðone ðæt lond biwepeð 63 ðe Carolus and Frederich bewepað lybbende:
64 nu he cann hu ðæt heofon lufað 65 rihtwisne cyning, and on his leoman 66 ðæs scinendan ðæt he geswutelað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Chi crederebbe giù nel mondo errante 68 che Rifëo Troiano in questo tondo 69 fosse la quinta de le luci sante?
70 Ora conosce assai di quel che ’l mondo 71 veder non può de la divina grazia, 72 ben che sua vista non discerna il fondo».
query.result:
**English:**
67 Who in the wandering world below would believe 68 that Trojan Ripheus is in this circle, 69 among the holy lights of the fifth rank?
70 Now he knows much of what the world 71 cannot see of divine grace, 72 although his sight does not perceive its depths.
**Old English:**
67 Hwa on ðisse worulde wenan wolde 68 ðæt Ripheus Troianus on ðisne stede 69 wære on ðære fiftan leohta gefean?
70 Nu he wat mare ðæs ðe ðeos world 71 ne mæg ymbclyppan of ðære godcundan gife, 72 ðeah ðe his gesihð ðæs grund ne mæge geseon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Quale allodetta che ’n aere si spazia 74 prima cantando, e poi tace contenta 75 de l’ultima dolcezza che la sazia,
76 tal mi sembiò l’imago de la ’mprenta 77 de l’etterno piacere, al cui disio 78 ciascuna cosa qual ell’ è diventa.
query.result:
**English:**
73 Like a lark that soars in the air, 74 singing at first, and then falls silent, content 75 with the final sweetness that satisfies it,
76 so did the image of the imprint 77 of eternal pleasure seem to me, for whose desire 78 each thing becomes what it is.
**Old English:**
73 Swa swa ðone laferce ðe on lyfte fleoð, 74 ærest singende, and ðonne swigeð blíðe 75 ðære æftemestan swetnesse ðe híe gesæled,
76 ðus ðuhte me ðæt gesyhð ðære inbryrde 77 ðæs écan wuldres, ðæs ðæs wilnunga 78 ælc ðing wyrðð swa swa hit is.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 E avvegna ch’io fossi al dubbiar mio 80 lì quasi vetro a lo color ch’el veste, 81 tempo aspettar tacendo non patio,
82 ma de la bocca, «Che cose son queste?», 83 mi pinse con la forza del suo peso: 84 per ch’io di coruscar vidi gran feste.
query.result:
**English:**
79 And although I was, in my doubt, 80 there like glass to the color that it wears, 81 I did not endure waiting in silence for long,
82 but from my mouth, "What things are these?", 83 the force of my desire pushed me to say, 84 so that I saw great celebrations of flashing light.
**Old English:**
79 And ðeah ðe ic wære on ðam tweon mínum 80 ðær swá glæs tó ðam híwe ðe hit wríð, 81 tíd ic ne ðóhte ðæt ic ðær ðolian sceolde,
82 ac of ðære múðe, "Hwæt ðing sind ðás?", 83 me ðæs wilna gewiofu tó ðam worde dræfde: 84 ðurh ðæt ic geseah micle gefean scínende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Poi appresso, con l’occhio più acceso, 86 lo benedetto segno mi rispuose 87 per non tenermi in ammirar sospeso:
88 «Io veggio che tu credi queste cose 89 perch’ io le dico, ma non vedi come; 90 sì che, se son credute, sono ascose.
query.result:
**English:**
85 Then soon after, with keener eyes, 86 the blessed sign answered me 87 so as not to keep me suspended in wonder:
88 "I see that you believe these things 89 because I tell them to you, but you do not see how; 90 so that, if they are believed, they are hidden.
**Old English:**
85 Þa sona æfter, mid gesihðe selran, 86 ðæt halige tacn andswarode me 87 ðy læs ic wære on wundrunge gehealden:
88 "Ic geseo ðæt ðu gelyfst ðisum ðingum 89 forðæm ðe ic ða secge, ac ðu ne gesihst hu; 90 swa ðæt, gif ða sind gelyfede, ða sind ða digle."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Fai come quei che la cosa per nome 92 apprende ben, ma la sua quiditate 93 veder non può se altri non la prome.
query.result:
**English:**
91 Do like those who learn the thing by name 92 well, but cannot see its quiddity 93 unless someone else explains it to them.
**Old English:**
91 Do swa ða ðe ða ðing be naman 92 wel cunnon, ac ða hwatnes 93 ne magon geseon buton him mon tæce.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Regnum celorum vïolenza pate 95 da caldo amore e da viva speranza, 96 che vince la divina volontate:
97 non a guisa che l’omo a l’om sobranza, 98 ma vince lei perché vuole esser vinta, 99 e, vinta, vince con sua beninanza.
query.result:
**English:**
94 The Kingdom of Heaven suffers violence 95 from fervent love and lively hope, 96 which conquer the divine will:
97 not in the way that one man has power over another, 98 but it conquers God because he wants to be conquered, 99 and, conquered, he conquers with his goodness.
**Old English:**
94 Þæt heofonrice ðolað wælhreownesse 95 of hatre lufu and of lybbendre hyhte, 96 þe ða godcundan willan oferwinnað:
97 nis hit swa swa man ofer man ofermægen hæfð, 98 ac hit oferwinð God forðæm þe he gewilnað beon oferwunnen, 99 and, oferwunnen, he oferwinð mid his godnysse.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 La prima vita del ciglio e la quinta 101 ti fa maravigliar, perché ne vedi 102 la regïon de li angeli dipinta.
query.result:
**English:**
100 The first age is depicted at the edge, and the fifth 101 makes you marvel, because you see there 102 the region of the angels painted.
**Old English:**
100 Þæt frumsceaft æt ðam bræde and ðæt fifte 101 ðe gewundrað, forðam ðu ðær gesyhst 102 engla rice gewriten.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 D’i corpi suoi non uscir, come credi, 104 Gentili, ma Cristiani, in ferma fede 105 quel d’i passuri e quel d’i passi piedi.
query.result:
**English:**
103 From his body did not come forth, as you believe, 104 pagans, but Christians, in firm faith, 105 he of the pierced hands and feet.
**Old English:**
103 Of his body ne comon, swa ðu wenst, 104 hæðene, ac cristene, on fæstum geleafan, 105 se ðara ðurhstochenra handa and fota.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Ché l’una de lo ’nferno, u’ non si riede 107 già mai a buon voler, tornò a l’ossa; 108 e ciò di viva spene fu mercede:
109 di viva spene, che mise la possa 110 ne’ prieghi fatti a Dio per suscitarla, 111 sì che potesse sua voglia esser mossa.
query.result:
**English:**
106 For one of Hell, from which one never returns 107 to good will, returned to the bones; 108 and this was the reward of living hope:
109 of living hope, which put the power 110 in the prayers made to God to resurrect her, 111 so that her will could be moved.
**Old English:**
106 For ðære helle, ðanon nan ne cymeð 107 æfre eft to ðam godan willan, gewende eft to ðam banum; 108 and ðæt wæs ðære lybbendan hyhte mede:
109 ðære lybbendan hyhte, ðe ða mihte gesette 110 on ða gebedu ðe wæron to Gode geworhte ðæt heo arise, 111 swa ðæt hire willa moste beon afylled.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 L’altra, per grazia che da sì profonda 119 fontana stilla, che mai creatura 120 non pinse l’occhio infino a la prima onda,
121 tutto suo amor là giù pose a drittura: 122 per che, di grazia in grazia, Dio li aperse 123 l’occhio a la nostra redenzion futura;
124 ond’ ei credette in quella, e non sofferse 125 da indi il puzzo più del paganesmo; 126 e riprendiene le genti perverse.
query.result:
**English:**
118 The other, by grace that from so deep 119 a fountain trickles that no creature 120 ever raised his eye to the first wave,
121 placed all his love below, in uprightness: 122 wherefore, from grace to grace, God opened 123 his eye to our future redemption;
124 whence he believed in that, and from then on 125 he could no longer endure the stench 126 of paganism; and he rebuked 127 the perverse people.
**Old English:**
118 Se oder, ðurh ða gyfe ðe of ðam deopan 119 welle spryngð, ðe næfre nænig gesceaft 120 ne ðohte ðæt eage oð ðone forman yð,
121 ealle his lufe ðær nyðerrihte gesette: 122 for ðam, of gyfe on gyfe, God him ontýnde 123 ðæt eage to ure toweardan alysednysse;
124 ðanon he on ða gelyfde, and ðanon forð 125 ðæs hæðenscipes stenc ne mihte ðolian; 126 and ða wyrrestan men ðærfore wregde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Quelle tre donne li fur per battesmo 128 che tu vedesti da la destra rota, 129 dinanzi al battezzar più d’un millesmo.
query.result:
**English:**
127 Those three ladies were his godmothers 128 whom you saw at the right wheel, 129 before his baptism more than a thousand years.
**Old English:**
127 Þa þreo wæron his godsibbas 128 þe þu gesawe fram þære swiðran hweole, 129 ær his fulluhte ma þonne þusend geara.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 O predestinazion, quanto remota 131 è la radice tua da quelli aspetti 132 che la prima cagion non veggion tota!
133 E voi, mortali, tenetevi stretti 134 a giudicar: ché noi, che Dio vedemo, 135 non conosciamo ancor tutti li eletti;
136 ed ènne dolce così fatto scemo, 137 perché il ben nostro in questo ben s’affina, 138 che quel che vole Iddio, e noi volemo».
query.result:
**English:**
130 O predestination, how remote 131 is your root from those aspects 132 that the first cause does not see entirely!
133 And you, mortals, restrain yourselves 134 from judging: for we, who see God, 135 do not yet know all the elect;
136 and this lack is sweet to us, 137 because our good is refined in this good, 138 that what God wills, we also will.
**Old English:**
130 Eala, foregesceaft, hu fela is 131 ðin wuduweard fram ðæm gesceaftum 132 ðe ðone ærestan anginn ne geseoð ealne!
133 And ge, deade, gehealdað eow fæste 134 wið ðam dome: forðæm we, ðe God geseoð, 135 ne cunnon gýt ealle ða gecorenan;
136 and ðæt is us swetlic swylc wanung, 137 forðæm ðe ure god on ðam gode bið gefinod, 138 ðæt ðæt God wile, and we willað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Così da quella imagine divina, 140 per farmi chiara la mia corta vista, 141 data mi fu soave medicina.
query.result:
**English:**
139 Thus from that divine image, 140 to make my short sight clear, 141 gentle medicine was given to me.
**Old English:**
139 Swa fram ðære godcundan ansyne, 140 ðurh ðæt ðe min scearp gesihð wære, 141 wæs me sylfum sellic læcedom forgifen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 E come a buon cantor buon citarista 143 fa seguitar lo guizzo de la corda, 144 in che più di piacer lo canto acquista,
145 sì, mentre ch’e’ parlò, sì mi ricorda 146 ch’io vidi le due luci benedette, 147 pur come batter d’occhi si concorda,
148 con le parole mover le fiammette.
query.result:
**English:**
142 And as a good singer, a good lutenist 143 makes the melody of the string resonate, 144 in which the song acquires more pleasure,
145 so, while he spoke, I remember 146 that I saw the two blessed lights, 147 just as the blinking of eyes is synchronized,
148 move the flames with the words.
**Old English:**
142 And swa swa god sangere, god hearpere 143 ðone streng ðære strenge ðe he stirred, 144 on ðære ðe ðæt leoð wynsumra bið,
145 swa ða ða he spræc, ða gemunde ic 146 ðæt ic ða twa leoht geseah beorhte, 147 swa swa ðæs eagan beorhtnes bið geþungen,
148 mid ðam wordum ða ligettas hweorfan.
